Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High Efficiency Tandem Perovskite-Copper Indium Selenide Solar Cell

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
Non-technical:
Solar photovoltaic (PV) energy conversion is an important technology for generating low-cost electricity to replace coal-generated power. It is also very important for providing electricity to half of the people in the world who currently lack grid-connected power. For economical generation of PV power, efficiency of solar cells is a very important consideration, since area-related costs such as encapsulation, wiring and structure decrease proportionately as the efficiency of the cell increases. A very recent development in this field has been the discovery that a new thin film material, hybrid organic-inorganic metal halide based perovskites, can be used to generate PV power with a conversion efficiency of ~20%. This new material has a larger bandgap than commonly used thin film materials such as copper-indium-gallium selenide (CIGS), and therefore, can be used as a higher bandgap first cell in a monolithic tandem solar cell arrangement with CIGS. Calculations predict that such a series-connected tandem cell structures can increase the efficiency of thin film CIGS solar cells to 30% from the current value of 20%, a 50% increase. This proposal is aimed towards fundamental material and device research to achieve such high efficiency tandem cell structures. It is hoped that such a structure will lead to further developments which result in a significant decrease in the cost of solar-electric power. A graduate student will participate in this project and new teaching materials will be incorporated into courses dealing with solar energy conversion.

Technical:

The proposal is focused on designing and fabricating a monolithic tandem cell structure with a high gap perovskite cell deposited on top of a high efficiency CIGS cell. The two cells are connected using novel tunnel junctions. Several new materials, processes and device structures need to be developed for the concept to work. Among these are:
-A perovskite material with a bandgap in the 1.7-1.8 eV range as opposed to the current 1.57 eV material. The higher bandgap is needed to make efficient tandem cells with a CIGS bottom cell. We will develop efficient Pb(I-Br) perovskites to increase the bandgap.
-A perovskite material which is physically stable at higher temperatures so that transparent contacts can be deposited on the device to allow light to be incident form the top of the cell. We will use novel organic precursors such as formamidinium iodide and urea hydroiodide to achieve thermally stable perovskites.
-A new vacuum process for depositing perovskites at higher temperatures which avoids the instability of the solution growth process.
-The use of inorganic heterojunction layers for electron and hole extraction , thus avoiding unstable organic heterojunction layers.
-ITO/ZnO tunnel junctions to connect the two cells.
-Innovative CIGS cells in1.1 to1.15 eV range with high efficiency achieved by using bandgap grading strategies along with larger grain growth and deliberate Na or K doping.
The project includes comprehensive material and device analysis tasks so as to understand the physics of the device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the photovoltaics industry matures, increasing module efficiency by overcoming the performance limitations of single junction solar cells is a key path to further reducing the cost of electricity. This project has focused on increasing the efficiency of inexpensive solar cells while keeping the processing costs low by developing the fundamental technology for a thin film monolithic tandem junction solar cell. This tandem structure increases the potential efficiency by effectively splitting the incoming light with higher energy light absorbed in a top cell using a lead-halide perovskite solar cell. The lower energy light passes through to be absorbed in a bottom cell based on the chalcopyrite material copper indium diselenide (or CIS). A tunnel junction layer is interposed between the two cells to allow for a series connection. The bandgaps of these two materials (~1.7 eV and 1.0 eV) are almost perfectly matched for achieving the highest efficiency in this tandem cell design. The materials are all thin films that can be continuously processed and layers on the order of 1 µm or less to potentially enable very low-cost manufacturing.

 The primary goals specific to the IEC project were to develop an efficient low bandgap CIS cell by controlled alloying, alkali doping and controlling recombination. Specific objectives to achieve this goal were:

  • Develop a three-stage co-evaporation process for depositing the critical CIS light absorbing layers with controlled through-film composition.
  • Determine effects of alloying the CIS with small amounts of silver, which has shown to improve the efficiency of wider bandgap solar cells, and gallium, which is used in the highest efficiency chalcopyrite solar cells but must be limited to small concentrations for the tandem cell application.
  • Investigate surface modification of the absorber layers using in-situ alkali (sodium or potassium) treatments to improve the surface properties for enhanced device performance.
  • Characterize material properties, quantify device losses and relate them to process parameters and film composition.

 The main outcomes of the research project provided an advanced understanding of the investigated alloying and surface treatment effects. It was determined that the silver alloying, even at relatively low concentrations of only a few percent increase the ability of the cell to respond to the low energy light it collects in the tandem configuration. Surface modifications, particularly a potassium post-deposition treatment, could improve the properties of the solar cell if carefully controlled. But when the silver alloying and post deposition surface treatment were combined, the output voltage, and therefore efficiency, of the solar cells decreased. This indicates that chemistry between potassium and silver results in a surface layer that degrades the critical junction in the solar cell. So, the best solar cell was produced using just the CIS absorbing layer with the surface treatment. With the highest performing solar cells in the project, a record efficiency of 16.0% for this material was demonstrated and validated by measurements at the National Renewable Energy Lab. The previous record cell was 15.0%.

 The majority of the research in the project was performed by a Ph.D. student in the department of Materials Science and Engineering. He presented technical results at two international conferences and has submitted two additional papers to date for publication in refereed journals. Other outcomes of the project included several outreach activities to explain and promote solar energy in the broader community.
